trello_data.desc:
## The latest in my series of Google Sheets hacks. 

After using my Tactical Roadmap for a few months, I realized that I had a few blind spots. It was good for staying alive, but less great for meeting savings goals in the long term. It felt a little bit like treading water. 

To solve this, I've put together a simple year-long life planner. It lets you quantify the stuff you want to spend your year on, and ties that to income and spending. It works in three layers:

### 1. Focus
For blocking out the broad strokes of your goals. What does the shape of your year look like? What do you want to achieve in 3 months? 6 months? A year? 

### 2. Attention
How much time and mental energy do you want to spend on each area of your life? Are you overcommitting yourself? Does something need to change in your relationships? 

### 3. Money
How much cash will you earn (or spend) from each area of your life? Moving house? Investing in travel, or professional development? Spooling up some passive income?

So far this is a pretty basic MVP which you can check out below. I'm making it a bit more automatic at the moment so I can use it to figure out my own 2017. 

In the meantime, I ran a workshop using this framework and got the following user feedback:

> I've realised that what it did is make me value all the work I am currently doing a lot more than I otherwise would. Just seeing all the stuff I do laid out made me really proud of how much I am putting out into the world even if there is no immediate monetary compensation. 

> I think valuing your own work is an important step in actually being able to turn it into an income stream so I was pretty stoked about that. 

---

# [Check out a non-interactive demo here](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1XeMhB4plHXgx4D5YvYprGT5QwCxkxvdtQSezSzRVzkQ/edit?usp=sharing)
trello_data.name: 🎲 Life Planner (MVP)

trello_data.desc:
## Keeping my finances in order was always hard for me. 

It was tricky to model the future consequences of my decisions. I would spend too much on groceries; take on less work than I should. It was stressful not knowing if I would be able to meet rent next month. 

This made it hard to plan out my day-to-day actions. 

### I would spend hours each week questioning:

- Am I working on the right thing this week?
- Do I have the luxury of spending a week on professional development?
- How fast do I need to turn this project around to meet rent?
- Will I ever get out of overdraft? 
- When do I need to start landing another contract? 

"Tactical Roadmap" is my attempt to solve this. It gives the user a holistic overview of money, time, and attention over a 13 week period.

It's designed to be used "envelope style"—i.e. with many buckets to earmark money for stuff like rent. Numbers can be exhausting to stare at, so I also designed it such that you **shouldn't have to even have read the numbers to get the gist.** 

### It features:

- A GANT-chart style overview of things in your attention and how much they'll earn. 
- Heavy use of colour to represent balances over time. Seeing lots of numbers at once numbs your brain. Subtle gradation of colour gives you a better idea of the "shape" of your money.
- HEAPS of emoji/iconography to allow the user to rapidly parse a fairly complex data set. 
- A money allocation system that lets you route income to the appropriate envelopes. 
- Automatic calculation/deduction of tax. 

Complexity is abstracted away into behind the scenes calculations and collapsible rows. In the future, I envision most input will happen in a Google Form or a simple web-app that pushes to Sheets via its API.

I now spend only about 20 minutes a week on money and scheduling and generally stress a whole lot less. 

---

# [You can check out an interactive demo here.](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Z336c6gB7WGnuvFcZPE4wRqwVnZpsrDDFLThaeovHGo/edit?usp=sharing)
trello_data.name: 📈 Tactical Roadmap (0.2)

trello_data.desc:
## An experiment for intuitively balancing the commitments in your life. 

The "Mediterranean Calendar" is an emoji-heavy, vibe-based calendar for balancing your week.

I made this because I had trouble figuring out how to balance my life. I found myself spending too much time working; or too much time doing the same things with my partner. 

I tried using calendars to enforce a bit of balance ("So I'll spend Tuesday night with myself...") but they are too specific! And actual appointments got lost in a sea of notifications. 

So, with the Med Calendar: You drop an icon into a slot, and it colour codes itself automagically.  Instead of dealing in specific time slots like "10:00–12:00: Work", we have  "Morning-ish:💰 ". 

At a glance, just by looking at the icons and the colour, you can get a feel for the tempo of your energy over the next week. Looking like a stressful week? Make some time for 🍻  or a 🎥 ! Trying to work on yourself a bit more this week? Make time for a 🚶🏼 and a 🤔 ! Nothing but 💰 all week? Give yourself a 🎉 at the end of it! 

The Med. Calendar currently exists as a Google Sheet (the best prototyping tool.) You simply drop in an emoji, merge a few cells and conditional formatting takes care of the rest. 

In the future, this will probably turn into a simple web-app (on React or similar) that could be used by digital nomads and remote workers—who tend to work strange hours by virtue of their lifestyle.

# [Check out a (read-only) demo here.](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1hrGrkH_7NFhOhDQ6uvWP7pnRlIfUpj1SB7TvAS94RJ8/edit#gid=0)
trello_data.name: ☀️ Mediterranean Calendar (MVP)

trello_data.desc:
## I built this to teach financial literacy in my tenure at Live the Dream. Participants were set to graduate the accelerator and had to set venture goals. 

The idea of a "business making money" was still an abstract concept for most of them. To solve this, I built a series of calculators that anchored their venture's financial needs to familiar concepts. Namely:

1. How much money do I need to survive?
2. How many hours do I want to work on my venture, per week?
3. What can I sell? 
4. How much can I sell it for?
5. What projects and milestones do I want to hit this year? 
6. What sources of funding may I need to sort to hit these goals? 

By breaking down a complex series of questions into a few simple steps, participants were able to devise business plans that made sense. They were able to do this with little experience or prompting. 

# [An example of a completed worksheet can be found here.](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1RVilMrDObxvuLZ49BLM6hKrEQGrrd06pP3lEqDBUsWs/edit?usp=sharing)
# [An interactive, blank one can be found here, if you want to play with it.](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1HGc_PQrcK-u6uXuwbrQF2DZI1N1gF1Cn0hAM0iCR6ZA/edit#gid=0)
trello_data.name: 💹 Financial Models 101 (0.1)

trello_data.desc:
## When I was a nomad, I was working from cafés all over South America. 

It was hard to keep things organized when I had nothing but a 13" screen and no fixed abode. This became a problem when I was juggling multiple projects. Todo lists built up everywhere, I lost windows and documents I needed—it was exhausting.

I was a big fan of OSX's Spaces, but they fail big at glanceability. When you have 20 Textedit windows, 5 instances of Chrome and dozens of other things open at once, stuff gets mixed up. 

I came up with this prototype of a solution: a series of images which I keep open (in Preview) and position over the top of all my windows. When I'm not using a space, everything is cloaked and colour-coded. 

Eventually I want to build this out as a simple app using Node & Electron. Pick an emoji, colour and title and the app does the rest. 

For now, this is hyper effective at creating virtual contexts for the different kinds of work I do on a weekly basis. I get distracted way less as well—with social media & email relegated to their own Spaces.
trello_data.name: 🎹 Better Spaces (MVP)
